quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: Free-Body Diagrams, Newton's Third Law, and Applied Forces (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Force Diagrams, Action-Reaction Pairs, Gravity, and Friction

questions.question: What is the purpose of a free-body diagram?
options: To show an object's velocity over time
To visualize all forces acting on a single object
questions.explanation: Free-body diagrams show all forces acting on one object, helping analyze net force and motion.

questions.question: Which force always acts perpendicular to a surface?
questions.explanation: The normal force is always perpendicular (normal) to the surface supporting an object.

questions.question: Newton's Third Law states that:
options: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction
Objects at rest stay at rest
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law describes action-reaction pairs between two different objects.

questions.question: A book rests on a table. What is the reaction force to Earth's gravity pulling down on the book?
options: The table pushing up on the book
The book pulling up on Earth
The book pushing down on the table
questions.explanation: The reaction to Earth pulling the book down is the book pulling Earth up with equal force.

questions.question: What is the formula for weight?
questions.explanation: Weight = mass × gravitational acceleration (W = mg).

questions.question: A 70 kg person stands on Earth (g = 9.8 m/s²). What is their weight?
Which type of friction is greater for the same surfaces?
questions.explanation: Static friction is generally greater than kinetic friction for the same surfaces.

questions.question: A car's tires push backward on the road. What is the reaction force?
options: The road pushing the car forward
questions.explanation: The road pushes forward on the tires - this is the reaction that propels the car.

questions.question: In a free-body diagram for a book resting on a table, which forces are shown?
options: Gravity and the table pushing up
Only the forces the book exerts
questions.explanation: Free-body diagrams show only forces acting ON the object: gravity down and normal force up.

questions.question: What happens to air resistance as an object's speed increases?
questions.explanation: Air resistance increases with speed, eventually balancing weight at terminal velocity.

questions.question: A person pushes against a wall with 100 N of force. What is the reaction force?
options: The floor pushing the person up
The wall pushing back with 100 N
questions.explanation: The wall pushes back on the person with equal 100 N force (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: What is the coefficient of friction?
options: A number representing how rough surfaces are
questions.explanation: The coefficient of friction (μ) is a dimensionless number representing surface roughness.

questions.question: The formula for friction force is:
questions.explanation: Friction force = coefficient of friction × normal force (f = μN).

questions.question: Why don't action-reaction forces cancel each other?
options: They act on the same object
They are in the same direction
questions.explanation: Action-reaction pairs act on different objects, so they don't cancel for either object.

questions.question: A 50 kg box rests on a horizontal surface. What is the normal force?
questions.explanation: Normal force balances weight: N = mg = 50 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 490 N.

questions.question: Which force opposes the start of motion?
questions.explanation: Static friction opposes the start of motion between stationary surfaces.

questions.question: A rocket accelerates upward in space. How does it work?
questions.explanation: Rockets expel gas downward, and the reaction force pushes the rocket upward (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: What is terminal velocity?
options: Speed when acceleration stops due to balanced forces
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity occurs when air resistance equals weight, resulting in zero net force and constant speed.

questions.question: A 10 kg object on Earth has weight 98 N. On the Moon (g = 1.6 m/s²), what is its weight?
questions.explanation: W = mg = 10 kg × 1.6 m/s² = 16 N. Mass stays the same, weight changes with gravity.

questions.question: Which diagram correctly shows forces on a car moving right at constant speed?
options: Large arrow right, small arrow left
questions.explanation: Constant speed means zero net force - engine force right equals friction/air resistance left.

questions.question: Why does a rough surface have more friction than a smooth one?
questions.explanation: Rough surfaces have more microscopic features that interlock, increasing friction.

questions.question: A fish swims by pushing water backward. What is the reaction?
questions.explanation: The water pushes forward on the fish - this reaction propels the fish forward.

questions.question: What is the normal force on a 20 kg object on a 30° incline?
Which pair are action-reaction forces?
options: Gravity on book and normal force on book
Foot kicks ball and ball pushes foot
questions.explanation: Foot on ball and ball on foot are action-reaction pairs between two objects.

questions.question: Why does oil reduce friction?
options: It creates a smooth layer between surfaces
questions.explanation: Lubricants create a smooth fluid layer that separates surfaces, reducing direct contact and friction.

questions.question: A skydiver reaches terminal velocity when:
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, upward air resistance equals downward weight, giving zero net force.

questions.question: What force causes a car to accelerate forward?
options: The engine pushing on the car
The road pushing on the tires
questions.explanation: The road pushes forward on the tires - this external force accelerates the car.

questions.question: A 5 kg box requires 25 N to start moving. What is μₛ?
Why can a tiny rocket work in space?
options: Newton's Third Law works in vacuum
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law works everywhere - expelling mass creates reaction force regardless of atmosphere.

questions.question: What is the friction force on a 100 N box if μₖ = 0.3 and it's moving?
questions.explanation: fₖ = μₖN = 0.3 × 100 N = 30 N (assuming horizontal surface, N = weight)

questions.question: A person jumps off a small boat. What happens?
questions.explanation: Both move in opposite directions due to action-reaction forces.

questions.question: What is the direction of friction on a tire that is accelerating a car forward?
questions.explanation: For acceleration, friction pushes forward on the tires from the road.

questions.question: Why does mass stay the same on different planets while weight changes?
options: Mass and weight are the same
questions.explanation: Mass is amount of matter (constant), weight = mg depends on local gravity.

questions.question: A 60 kg person on a scale in an elevator sees 660 N. What is the elevator doing?
questions.explanation: Normal force = m(g+a) = 60(9.8+a) = 660, so a = 1.2 m/s² upward.

questions.question: What is the reaction to a hammer hitting a nail?
questions.explanation: The nail pushes back on the hammer with equal force (Newton's Third Law).

questions.question: Why is it hard to start a heavy object moving?
options: Static friction must be overcome first
questions.explanation: Static friction is greater than kinetic friction, making it harder to start motion.

questions.question: A book slides to a stop. What force causes the deceleration?
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction opposes the motion, causing deceleration.

questions.question: What happens to terminal velocity if mass increases?
questions.explanation: Heavier objects need more air resistance to balance weight, so they reach higher terminal velocities.

questions.question: A free-body diagram for a falling object with air resistance shows:
options: Gravity down and air resistance up
Gravity up and air resistance down
questions.explanation: Gravity pulls down, air resistance pushes up - both act on the falling object.

questions.question: Why does a balloon move forward when air escapes backward?
questions.explanation: Air pushed backward, balloon pushed forward - action-reaction pair.

questions.question: What is the weight of a 1 kg object on Earth?
questions.explanation: W = mg = 1 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 9.8 N.

questions.question: Which surface would have the highest coefficient of friction?
questions.explanation: Rubber on dry concrete has high friction due to surface interlocking.

questions.question: A person pulls a sled with 50 N at 30° above horizontal. What is the normal force?
questions.explanation: The upward component of the pull reduces the normal force.

questions.question: Why do brakes work better on dry roads than wet roads?
questions.explanation: Water acts as a lubricant, reducing the friction coefficient between tires and road.

questions.question: What is the net force on an object at terminal velocity?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, air resistance equals weight, so net force is zero.

questions.question: A 500 N crate is pushed with 200 N but doesn't move. What is the friction force?
questions.explanation: Static friction matches the applied force up to its maximum value.

questions.question: Why do rockets have multiple stages?
options: To reduce mass and increase acceleration
questions.explanation: Dropping empty stages reduces mass, allowing greater acceleration (a = F/m).

questions.question: What force allows walking?
questions.explanation: Foot pushes ground backward, ground pushes foot forward (action-reaction).

questions.question: A 2 kg object has weight 19.6 N on Earth. On Jupiter (g = 24.8 m/s²), what is its mass?
questions.explanation: Mass remains 2 kg everywhere - it's the amount of matter.

questions.question: Why do cars have tread patterns on tires?
options: To channel water away and maintain friction
questions.explanation: Treads channel water away to maintain tire-road contact and friction on wet surfaces.

questions.question: What is the direction of friction on a braking car's tires?
questions.explanation: For braking, the road pushes backward on the tires, creating friction that opposes the car's forward motion and causes deceleration.

questions.question: A person stands on one foot instead of two. What happens to pressure?
questions.explanation: Same weight over half the area doubles the pressure (though this is more about pressure than forces).

questions.question: Why do falling leaves flutter?
questions.explanation: Changing orientation causes varying air resistance, making leaves flutter rather than fall straight.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered force diagrams and Newton's Third Law applications.
scoreMessages.70: Very Good! You understand most concepts but should review friction calculations.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort! Focus on practicing free-body diagrams and action-reaction pairs.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review Newton's Third Law and friction concepts.
